intro: Galium tuncelianum, commonly known as the creeping bedstraw, is a low-growing herbaceous perennial native to parts of Europe and Asia. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its prostrate or ascending stems that often root at the nodes. The plant produces small, white or pale yellow flowers arranged in clusters, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are opposite, ovate to elliptic, and covered with fine hairs. Galium tuncelianum thrives in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks.
